awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Kinetic and Spectroscopic Studies of Catalytically Versatile Non-heme Mononuclear Iron Enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Yisong Guo from Carnegie Mellon University to study three enzyme-catalyzed reactions that are required to make novel highly bioactive compounds in microorganisms.  The three enzymes employ the same basic structure around the iron atom, yet carry out three quite different reactions; the reasons for this difference in structure-function relationship is a fundamental question in biological chemistry.  For example, iron in the same basic environment can result in the formation of carbon-oxygen bonds on the one hand or carbon sulfur bonds on the other.  The research applies cutting edge methodology to reveal just how these reactions take place on an atom-by-atom basis.  The research results may provide useful guidelines in designing new molecular catalysts and biocatalysts to perform these important and challenging chemical transformations.  Research supported by this award also provides a training ground for students in physical chemistry, bioinorganic chemistry, biochemistry, enzymology, and catalysis. The knowledge generated through this project is integrated into educational activities where graduate, undergraduate, and high school students play an active role in discovering how reactions are catalyzed by iron-dependent enzymes.  

Non-heme mononuclear iron (NHM-Fe) dependent enzymes catalyze exceedingly diverse enzymatic reactions, ranging from "classical" hydroxylation, to desaturation, epoxidation, halogenation, epimerization, aromatic ring expansion, ring contraction, and ring opening.  The structures of the iron centers catalyzing these diverse reactions are surprisingly simple.  The first coordination sphere of the iron only contains histidine (His) and/or aspartic/glutamic acid (Asp/Glu) residues.  The goal of this project is to provide a molecular level understanding of the similarity and difference of these structural motifs in controlling oxygen activation and the subsequent chemical transformations, as well as on the catalytic roles of redox active protein residues near the iron centers.  To achieve this goal, detailed mechanistic studies are conducted on three NHM-Fe enzymes that contain 2-His-1-Asp or 3-His iron binding motifs.  A combined biochemical, kinetic and spectroscopic approach is used.  This research is expected to provide crucial insights into the catalytic versatility of NHM-Fe enzymes.  The project includes a comprehensive educational program at the graduate and undergraduate levels and outreach to K-12 students around the concepts that relate to reaction rates and catalysis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The major goals of this award are to elucidate reaction mechanisms of O2-activating non-heme mononuclear iron-containing (NHM-Fe) enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of peroxy- and thiol-containing secondary metabolites and the O2 activation strategies used by the mononuclear iron centers in these enzymes ligated by different ligand sets. These metabolites show beneficial bioactivities towards human health, including antibiotic, anti-cancer and anti-aging activities. However, the molecular level understandings of key biosynthetic steps in the formation these secondary metabolites are largely missing. The main findings of this award are the identification and spectroscopic characterizations (Mössbauer, electron paramagnetic resonance, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy) of the first spin triplet (S = 1) non-heme iron(IV) reactive intermediate in a NHM-Fe enzyme, OvoA. OvoA catalyzes a O2-dependent carbon-sulfur bond formation, which leads to the cross coupling of free-standing histidine and cysteine and forms the key intermediate product in the biosynthesis of Ovothiol A (OSHA). OSHA is a naturally-occurring thiol-histidine derivative that exhibits anti-cancer bioactivity. Prior to this discovery, all the experimentally observed iron(IV) intermediates found in NHM-Fe enzymes are in an S = 2 spin ground state having an iron ligand set consisting of 2 histidines and 1 aspartic or glutamic acid (2-His-1-Asp/Glu). In contrast, the iron binding motif in OvoA consists of three His. Thus, a His-rich ligand environment could be the determining factor that leads to an S = 1 iron(IV) intermediate observed in OvoA instead of more commonly observed S = 2 spin state supported by the 2-His-1-Asp/Glu motif. It is well established that S = 2 iron(IV) intermediates are reactive and can perform radical chemistry, such as C-H bond activation. The S = 1 iron(IV) intermediate in OvoA does not carry out C-H bond activation. Thus, it seems that nature has developed a radical-reactivity tamed iron(IV) intermediate (S = 1) to perform other non-radical oxidative transformations, such as the C-S coupling reaction found in OvoA. This discovery sets the stage to expand our fundamental understanding on the non-heme high-valent iron intermediates supported by a ligand environment beyond the 2-His-1-Asp/Glu ligand set.

 

Broader Impacts:

The research goals and achievements in this award have been integrated into the educational activities, which included disseminating cutting-edge scientific results and research skills to graduate level, undergraduate level, and K-12 level students by teaching chemical kinetics, enzyme catalysis and spectroscopy. This award has supported four graduate students and provided them with opportunities to obtain PhD training in metalloenzyme biochemistry and spectroscopy areas and to attend national and international scientific conferences to disseminate their research results. This award has also supported multiple undergraduate students for their undergraduate research activities, which broadened participation in STEM related research fields. Furthermore, this award has supported the creation of an outreach activity, titled “How enzyme works”, for disseminating the research results in this research project and the basic scientific knowledge about enzyme reactions to grades 6-9 students from regional high schools.


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Yisong Guo
